description: very interested, eager, or wanting (to do) something very much:

title: Prevalent
example: These diseases are more prevalent among young children.

description: existing very commonly or happening often:

title: Drone
example: drone of the drone of an engine

The drone of his voice made me feel sleepy.
unmanned drone The US Border Patrol's unmanned drone helped agents track down their smuggling suspect.
He shot some amazing aerial footage using his drone.
An airplane droned in the background.
I could hear the drone of an airplane.

description: a low continuous noise that does not change its note:

title: Hygrometer
example: Example not found

title: Peculiar
example: She has the most peculiar ideas.

UK The video on road accidents made me feel rather peculiar (= ill).

description: unusual and strange, sometimes in an unpleasant way:

title: Image
example: I have an image in my mind of how I want the garden to be.
fit your image He doesn't fit (= he is different to) my image of how an actor should look.
public image The aim is to improve the public image of the police.

television images of starving children

moving images on a TV screen
create/project/build an image The logo change is part of an ongoing effort to project a new image that will attract younger customers.
change/improve/protect sb's image Developers discussed how the impoverished town could improve its image and boost its redevelopment potential.

good/positive/strong image When working in sales, it is important that you present a positive image.
a bad/poor/negative image
sb's public/private/professional image These events give delegates the chance to network and improve their professional image.

You can rotate the image, resize it, zoom in, zoom out, or adjust its color.

a computer/digital/photographic image
black and white/greyscale/color image
description: a picture in your mind or an idea of how someone or something is:

title: Replenishment
example: Bone marrow plays an important role in the constant replenishment of red blood cells.

description: the act of filling something up again by replacing what has been used:

title: Remainder
example: I ate most of it and gave the remainder to the dog.

9 divided by 4 is 2, remainder 1.
His autobiography never sold very well and was soon remaindered.

the remainder of sth The remainder of its business, plastic packaging, makes up 20% of group sales.

All our remainders have been discounted by more than 50%.
Copies of his autobiography are now being remaindered.
description: the part of something that is left after the other parts have gone, been used, or been taken away:

title: Vane
example: Example not found
description: a flat, narrow part of a fan, propeller, etc. that turns because of the pressure of air or liquid against it

title: Monarchs

description: a king or queen:

title: Maiden
example: fair maiden In the story, the prince woos and wins the fair maiden.

his maiden appearance on TV
In the story, the prince woos the fair maiden.
a maiden voyage/flight
maiden flight/voyage The airline launched its Washington to Paris service with a maiden flight for journalists and investors.
maiden bond/dividend The phone operator is expected to pay a maiden dividend to shareholders next spring.
description: a girl or young woman:

title: Hamper

a laundry/picnic hamper
description: to prevent someone doing something easily:

title: Tram
example: I hopped off the tram near the park.
description: an electric vehicle that transports people, usually in cities, and goes along metal tracks in the road

title: Bear
example: The strain must have been enormous but she bore it well.
Tell me now! I can't bear the suspense!
[ + to infinitive ] He couldn't bear to see the dog in pain.
[ + -ing verb ] I can't bear being bored.
bear responsibility It's your decision - you have to bear the responsibility if things go wrong.
bear the burden They say that landlords should bear the burden of these repairs and not tenants.
bear the cost I suggest you claim on your insurance rather than bearing the cost yourselves.
"What if she'd been driving faster?" "It doesn't bear thinking about."
bear something in mind Thank you for your advice - I'll bear it in mind (= I will remember and consider it).
bear a resemblance to Their baby bears a strong resemblance to its grandfather.
bear no resemblance to The game is colourful and exciting, but bears no resemblance to (= is completely different from) real driving.
The stone plaque bearing his name was smashed to pieces.
On display were boxing gloves that bore Rocky Marciano's signature.
[ + two objects ] I don't bear them any ill feeling (= I do not continue to be angry with or dislike them).
bear someone's weight The chair, too fragile to bear her weight, collapsed.
bear the weight of I don't think that the table will bear the weight of the heavy machinery.
The pear tree they planted has never borne fruit.
She had borne six children by the time she was 30.
[ + two objects ] When his wife bore him a child he could not hide his delight.
Most animals bear their young in the spring.
bear gifts At Christmas the family all arrive at the house bearing gifts.
Countless waiters bore trays of drinks into the room.
The sound of the ice cream van was borne into the office on the wind.
bear left After you go past the church keep bearing left.
bear right Bear right at the fork in the road.
The path followed the coastline for several miles, then bore inland.
bear witness to She bore witness to his patience and diligence.

He accused his neighbour of bearing false witness against him.
A mother bear is fiercely protective of her cubs.
a brown/black bear
a black/grizzly/polar bear
Fans bearing banners ringed the stadium.
The bridge has to be strengthened to bear heavier loads.
[ T ] Since you will bear most of the responsibility, you should get the rewards.
[ + to infinitive ] He could not bear to see her suffering.

She bore three children in five years.

title: Contradictory
example: I keep getting contradictory advice - some people tell me to keep it warm and some tell me to put ice on it.
description: If two or more facts, pieces of advice, etc. are contradictory, they are very different from each other:

title: Strict
example: strict with My parents were very strict with me when I was young.

strict vegetarian She's a strict vegetarian and refuses to eat any poultry or fish.

Do you think stricter laws would help reduce automobile accidents?
